S THE day approaches for the
reckoning of the case of the
Honorable E. A. Schaal versus the
suzerains of the Central Y. M. C.
A., reminiscences of the recent New
Thought assembly crop up rather
pungently. Although the assembly
was reputedly devoted to the emancipation of the dormant undergraduate intelligence, little was emancipated on the occasion save a number of beautiful illustrations of mob
phenomena. The chief difficulty
encountered at the time was that of
keeping the gentlemen of Hopkins
on the same subject long enough to
discuss it.

A

From the ousting of Schaal by the
Y. M. C. A., supposedly for his
liberalism, they shifted to homilies
on Mr. Schaal's wife and children,
his powerful handshake, and the
sympathy that he offers to sad
freshmen. From deprecations of the
boys of the Trustee Board, they
swerved to proposals to buy Levering Hall. From plans to sweat a
gymnasium out of Shylock Iddins,
they jumped to plans to build the
swellest bon fire that Johns Hopkins had ever seen, by God! What
better denouement could there have
been to such an assembly than the
street brawl that actually followed?

D

T

to mediocre thoughts. It is as unChristian as it is conservative.
Just as the Y. M. C. A. is in
belligerent antithesis to intellectual
progress, just so it maintains a
similar attitude toward social progress. And no one will question
the statement that it is a conservative organization. Consequently, if
Mr. Schaal gives us his own word
for his liberalism and if the Central Y. M. C. A. is convinced that
Mr. Schaal is profaning thereby the
Y. M. C. A. and its swimming pools
and prayer rooms then there is as
little excuse for Mr. Schaal's presence in the Y. M. C. A. organization as there is for the Y. M. C. A.
organization's presence on the Johns
Hopkins campus!
Many have attempted to play up a
sort of maudlin pathos in the matter,
to wit: the tearing of embryo liberals from the bosom of the papa
liberal, Mr. Schaal. But to me the
whole business is so delightfully ridiculous that it almost eclipses all
)ther considerations. Consider, if

Mr. Schaal palpably is not a leader of campus thought. His periodic
camp meeting that goes under the

does not even. attract the Y. M. C.

credited as his achievement, is little
popular with graduates or undergraduates. Nor, indeed, in my opinion, is its liberalism unimpeachable.

style of Y. M. C. A. literature is
not a Student center for reasons
other than convenience and expedience. I, myself rarely make use of
the building outside of my connection with the NEWS-LETTER. And
judging by some of the specimens of journalism that appear
in both the Black and Blue Jay and
the NEWS-LETTER either could be
written in an alley as well as behind
mahogany desks.

sofas of Levering Hall are indispensible to Hopkins. No one particularly wants him to go. No one

he goes the Barnstormers will continue as they have continued, the

as heretofore. And if he stays . ..

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 13, 1931

BASKETEERS SHARE
WEEK-END HONORS
Jays Win Over Brooklyn
22-14; Lose To Army 41-33
LOSERS SLATED

TO

WIN

Kelly Stars In Both Games for
Johns Hopkins
After their surprising showing
against Loyola College last week the
Hopkins basketball team kept up
the good work an a trip to New
York State over the week-end. On
Friday night Brooklyn Poly fell before the Jay quint the score being
22-14. Saturday afternoon the Army
won a 41-33game from the Black
and Blue five at West Point. However as was the case against Loyola,
the Jays proved much stronger than
their rivals had expected.
Poly Unable To Score

Before meeting the Jays, the
Brooklyn team had won three
straight games and were given more
than an even chance to defeat the
Baltimore team. Don Kelly and Silverman, who had done good work
against the Loyola forwards, were
again on the job and the Poly team
could not break into the scoring
column during the first twenty minutes of play. In the meantime field
goals by Don Kelly, Jones and
Brook, and a foul goal by Jones
had enabled Hopkins to run upa
fairly safe margin and the half ended with the Jays enjoying a 9-0
lead.
With the start of the second half
the Brooklyn attack began to find
the range with the result that Wilson and Staehlick scored two
double-deckers apiece. Jansen, Poly
forward, was their high point scorer
with six points to his credit. These
points were the result of three field
goals.
Kelly Scores Four Goals

However, during this interval
the Jays had not been idle for Jones
had scored another field goal,
Brooks had made good on a free
throw, the result of a foul, and
Gunnett, who replaced the redhaired center later on, had counted
on a field goal. In addition Don
Kelly counted four double decker
and this total gave the Jays their
margin of victory.
Don Kelly was the high point
scorer of the evening with twelve
points credited to him. Jones with
five followed him, while Brooks
with three, and Gunnett with two
points were the other scorers. Silverman, although not among the
scorers, played a fine defensive
game and was instrumental in holding down the number of field goals
garnered by the New orkers.
The inability of the Poly team to
take advantage of their foul shots
cost them several points and aided
in their downfall.
Visitors Rush Jays

When Coach Darley's men lined
Up against Army Saturday afternoon they realized that they were in
for a struggle. As a matter of fact,
the Soldiers had just run a string
of three consecutive victories which
they intended not only to keep unbroken but which they wished to
extend at the expense of the Baltimoreans. Realizing this, the visiting quint started off with a rush.
Shortly after the opening jump,
Don Kelly sank one from the side
of the court. Herb, a member of
the Army backfield during the football season, made it 2-all after taking a pass from Blanning. Then
Brooks, rangy Jay center, scored a
field goal and when Blanning
fouled Silverman, the latter made
good on his free shot.
Cadets Take Lead

- THE MAIL BAG
Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
Frequently individuals of the
campus are .inspired with initiative
enough to make inquiries as to their
status quo in the policies of this
institution. There is one question
which I would wish answered because it has remained a mystery to
the unsophisticated collegian an unduly long time.
What has happened to the Cage
Fund drive?
Rumors have it that the Varsity
Club has taken the matter into their
own hands and are attempting to
finance the construction. Well and
good, but is there any verification
for this rumor?
The average student's conception
of the history and plans of the Cage
are not at all clarified. The class of
twenty-nine took the matter into
their hands when their chairman
was appointed. But due to no fault
of the capable chairman, sufficient
funds could not be raised and so
the matter apparently came to an
undignified and ignominious finish.
The other outside sources of revenue had already been tapped and
still the required quota had not been
attained. There was no other organization in any way affiliated with
the University who were depressed
about the failure to do anything
about it except the Varsity Club.
The rumor concerning their activities has this logical justification. It
it justly placed too for the Club
personifies those men who should
take an interest in the athletics of
the University, because they know
the needs at Homewood. And if
there is one thing that is a requisite
around campus, it is a place for
the indoor sports to have free lance.
It is rather a pathetic need too, for
Hopkins is one of a few modern
colleges that have no gymnasium of
any sort.
It would seem that other expenditures that the University has
liquidated could have been used to
a better advantage. The artificial
lighting system has proved rather
useless and void, football at night
does not have the attraction that the
old afternoon contests had, the
lighting can be used only two and a
half months in the year, Lacrosse
is impossible because the pellet can
not be seen and the money employed
in construction could well have been
utilized in the Cage Fund where its
advantage can in no way be doubted
nor impaired.
That has all passed and still the
question of Cage Fund remains a
mystery and a curiosity.
Would some one advise the campus in its entirety exactly what has
happened to the Cage Fund and its
future possibilities?
C. F.

Outline Comprehensive Examinations

Referring to the comprehensive
type of examinations, it was suggested by the committee that "in
general, the questions should avoid
searching detail and should be so
chosen as to show whether the student has a grasp, first, of the fundamental principles of his own and
closely allied subjects, and, second,
of the technique of workers in his
field."
Subsequent to consultation with
the various Departments in the
Hopkins, arrangements have been
made to offer additional new courses
in the curriculum in order that sufficient supplementary material for
the effective operation of the groupstudy system may be provided.
"Evils" Cited By Committee

It is the belief of the committee
that three practices now impede the
satisfactory educational training of
the student: (1) the determination
of a man's fitness for the A. B. degree on the number of Points-credit
he has acquired; (2) the lack of
provision for the organization of a
coherent education in the third and
fourth years; (3) the presentation
of lecture courses for upperclassmen, "which has put a premium
upon the student's receptivity and
discouraged that skeptical and inquiring spirit extremely important
in men who wish to contribute to
the progress of civilization rather
than be its beneficiaries alone."

Dr. Paul Harrison, a graduate
of Johns Hopkins Medical School
addressed the University Supper last night.

life and experiences, among the
natives of Arabia.

S THE day approaches for the
reckoning of the case of the
Honorable E. A. Schaal versus the
suzerains of the Central Y. M. C.
A., reminiscences of the recent New
Thought assembly crop up rather
pungently. Although the assembly
was reputedly devoted to the emancipation of the dormant undergraduate intelligence, little was emancipated on the occasion save a number of beautiful illustrations of mob
phenomena. The chief difficulty
encountered at the time was that of
keeping the gentlemen of Hopkins
on the same subject long enough to
discuss it.

A

From the ousting of Schaal by the
Y. M. C. A., supposedly for his
liberalism, they shifted to homilies
on Mr. Schaal's wife and children,
his powerful handshake, and the
sympathy that he offers to sad
freshmen. From deprecations of the
boys of the Trustee Board, they
swerved to proposals to buy Levering Hall. From plans to sweat a
gymnasium out of Shylock Iddins,
they jumped to plans to build the
swellest bon fire that Johns Hopkins had ever seen, by God! What
better denouement could there have
been to such an assembly than the
street brawl that actually followed?

to mediocre thoughts. It is as unChristian as it is conservative.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 13, 1931

BASKETEERS SHARE
WEEK-END HONORS
Jays Win Over Brooklyn
22-14; Lose To Army 41-33
LOSERS SLATED

TO

WIN

Kelly Stars In Both Games for
Johns Hopkins
After their surprising showing
against Loyola College last week the
Hopkins basketball team kept up
the good work an a trip to New
York State over the week-end. On
Friday night Brooklyn Poly fell before the Jay quint the score being
22-14. Saturday afternoon the Army
won a 41-33game from the Black
and Blue five at West Point. However as was the case against Loyola,
the Jays proved much stronger than
their rivals had expected.
Poly Unable To Score

Before meeting the Jays, the
Brooklyn team had won three
straight games and were given more
than an even chance to defeat the
Baltimore team. Don Kelly and Silverman, who had done good work
against the Loyola forwards, were
again on the job and the Poly team
could not break into the scoring
column during the first twenty minutes of play. In the meantime field
goals by Don Kelly, Jones and
Brook, and a foul goal by Jones
had enabled Hopkins to run upa
fairly safe margin and the half ended with the Jays enjoying a 9-0
lead.
With the start of the second half
the Brooklyn attack began to find
the range with the result that Wilson and Staehlick scored two
double-deckers apiece. Jansen, Poly
forward, was their high point scorer
with six points to his credit. These
points were the result of three field
goals.
Kelly Scores Four Goals

However, during this interval
the Jays had not been idle for Jones
had scored another field goal,
Brooks had made good on a free
throw, the result of a foul, and
Gunnett, who replaced the redhaired center later on, had counted
on a field goal. In addition Don
Kelly counted four double decker
and this total gave the Jays their
margin of victory.
Don Kelly was the high point
scorer of the evening with twelve
points credited to him. Jones with
five followed him, while Brooks
with three, and Gunnett with two
points were the other scorers. Silverman, although not among the
scorers, played a fine defensive
game and was instrumental in holding down the number of field goals
garnered by the New orkers.
The inability of the Poly team to
take advantage of their foul shots
cost them several points and aided
in their downfall.
Visitors Rush Jays

When Coach Darley's men lined
Up against Army Saturday afternoon they realized that they were in
for a struggle. As a matter of fact,
the Soldiers had just run a string
of three consecutive victories which
they intended not only to keep unbroken but which they wished to
extend at the expense of the Baltimoreans. Realizing this, the visiting quint started off with a rush.
Shortly after the opening jump,
Don Kelly sank one from the side
of the court. Herb, a member of
the Army backfield during the football season, made it 2-all after taking a pass from Blanning. Then
Brooks, rangy Jay center, scored a
field goal and when Blanning
fouled Silverman, the latter made
good on his free shot.
Cadets Take Lead

- THE MAIL BAG
Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
Frequently individuals of the
campus are .inspired with initiative
enough to make inquiries as to their
status quo in the policies of this
institution. There is one question
which I would wish answered because it has remained a mystery to
the unsophisticated collegian an unduly long time.
What has happened to the Cage
Fund drive?
Rumors have it that the Varsity
Club has taken the matter into their
own hands and are attempting to
finance the construction. Well and
good, but is there any verification
for this rumor?
The average student's conception
of the history and plans of the Cage
are not at all clarified. The class of
twenty-nine took the matter into
their hands when their chairman
was appointed. But due to no fault
of the capable chairman, sufficient
funds could not be raised and so
the matter apparently came to an
undignified and ignominious finish.
The other outside sources of revenue had already been tapped and
still the required quota had not been
attained. There was no other organization in any way affiliated with
the University who were depressed
about the failure to do anything
about it except the Varsity Club.
The rumor concerning their activities has this logical justification. It
it justly placed too for the Club
personifies those men who should
take an interest in the athletics of
the University, because they know
the needs at Homewood. And if
there is one thing that is a requisite
around campus, it is a place for
the indoor sports to have free lance.
It is rather a pathetic need too, for
Hopkins is one of a few modern
colleges that have no gymnasium of
any sort.
It would seem that other expenditures that the University has
liquidated could have been used to
a better advantage. The artificial
lighting system has proved rather
useless and void, football at night
does not have the attraction that the
old afternoon contests had, the
lighting can be used only two and a
half months in the year, Lacrosse
is impossible because the pellet can
not be seen and the money employed
in construction could well have been
utilized in the Cage Fund where its
advantage can in no way be doubted
nor impaired.
That has all passed and still the
question of Cage Fund remains a
mystery and a curiosity.
Would some one advise the campus in its entirety exactly what has
happened to the Cage Fund and its
future possibilities?
C. F.

records were broken shows that the
team made a very creditable showing.
Boyce, swimming in two previous

in the fine time of 6 minutes, 26 3/5
seconds.
Clip Seconds from Records

Outline Comprehensive Examinations

Referring to the comprehensive
type of examinations, it was suggested by the committee that "in
general, the questions should avoid
searching detail and should be so
chosen as to show whether the student has a grasp, first, of the fundamental principles of his own and
closely allied subjects, and, second,
of the technique of workers in his
field."
Subsequent to consultation with
the various Departments in the
Hopkins, arrangements have been
made to offer additional new courses
in the curriculum in order that sufficient supplementary material for
the effective operation of the groupstudy system may be provided.
"Evils" Cited By Committee

It is the belief of the committee
that three practices now impede the
satisfactory educational training of
the student: (1) the determination
of a man's fitness for the A. B. degree on the number of Points-credit
he has acquired; (2) the lack of
provision for the organization of a
coherent education in the third and
fourth years; (3) the presentation
of lecture courses for upperclassmen, "which has put a premium
upon the student's receptivity and
discouraged that skeptical and inquiring spirit extremely important
in men who wish to contribute to
the progress of civilization rather
than be its beneficiaries alone."

Dr. Paul Harrison Tells
Of His Twenty Years'
Stay In Arabia
Dr. Paul Harrison, a graduate
of Johns Hopkins Medical School
addressed the University Supper last night.
Dr. Harrison, who has spent
twenty years in medical work in
Arabia, gave an account of his
life and experiences, among the
natives of Arabia.
Dr. Harrison will speak at the
Assembly on Thursday, March 5.
